repo.description: Vim-fork focused on extensibility and usability
repo.name: neovim

body:
**Problem:** EditQuery currently shows captures in the original buffer using the Title highlight group, which can be too similar to other text.

I use a simple color scheme, I don't want to make titles too distinct, but I do want to distinguish captures from the rest of the code.

**Solution:** Use a virtual text diagnostic highlight group: they are displayed in a similar manner to the query captures so we can assume that the color scheme should have appropriate styling applied to make them visible.

(I filed #36259)

comment_data.body:
This (and your update to syntax.txt) are for "core" highlights. Not every single plugin needs a new "core" highlight. The highlight group can be defined in `dev.lua`.

Or alternatively, it *would* make sense to define a new core hightlight for a more generic concept. In https://github.com/neovim/neovim/issues/32646 I suggested something like an `Attention` highlight, which fits quite well with the purpose of this query-capture.

Another option is to just use `Visual` instead of `Title`.
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -181,6 +181,7 @@ static const char *highlight_init_both[] = {
   "default link ComplMatchIns    NONE",
   "default link ComplHint        NonText",
   "default link ComplHintMore    MoreMsg",
+  "default link QueryCapture     Title",

comment_data.body:
yeah, that didn't feel right. I was focused on maintaining the current choice of Title, so I didn't think about using a different existing group.

I think using `Visual` would work, or maybe `DiagnosticVirtualTextInfo` or `Hint`? Since it's going to be displayed as virtual text those are likely to have appropriate styling defined for that context.
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -181,6 +181,7 @@ static const char *highlight_init_both[] = {
   "default link ComplMatchIns    NONE",
   "default link ComplHint        NonText",
   "default link ComplHintMore    MoreMsg",
+  "default link QueryCapture     Title",

comment_data.body: `Visual` is already used for the matched text, so I'm going to use the Diagnostic groups.
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -181,6 +181,7 @@ static const char *highlight_init_both[] = {
   "default link ComplMatchIns    NONE",
   "default link ComplHint        NonText",
   "default link ComplHintMore    MoreMsg",
+  "default link QueryCapture     Title",

comment_data.body:
why use the "Virtual" variant? semantically `DiagnosticHint` fits better.

the variants like `DiagnosticVirtualTextHint`, `DiagnosticFloatingHint`, etc., only make sense in the context of diagnostics. Whereas in this context, we are just talking about a generic "Hint". It is 100% irrelevant that the current impl of `dev.lua` *happens* to use virtual text. If we later change the impl to display it some other way, it's just annoying that we would have to change the highlight name...

this btw is why I hate all these over-specific variants.
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -608,7 +608,7 @@ local function update_editor_highlights(query_win, base_win, lang)
           end_col = end_col,
           hl_group = 'Visual',
           virt_text = {
-            { capture_name, 'Title' },
+            { capture_name, 'DiagnosticVirtualTextHint' },

comment_data.body: undo this whitespace please. this paragraph has various notes about the UX, we don't need a separate paragraph for each sentence.
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -1196,9 +1196,11 @@ end
 --- Can also be shown with the [:EditQuery]() command. `:EditQuery <tab>` completes available
 --- parsers.
 ---
---- If you move the cursor to a capture name ("@foo"), text matching the capture is highlighted in
---- the source buffer. The query editor is a scratch buffer, use `:write` to save it. You can find
---- example queries at `$VIMRUNTIME/queries/`.
+--- If you move the cursor to a capture name ("@foo"), text matching the capture is highlighted
+--- with |hl-DiagnosticVirtualTextHint| in the source buffer.
+---

comment_data.body:
The rationale -- as far as I see it -- is that the point of the "Virtual" variant is to clearly distinguish them from actual buffer text (e.g., by being italic), which is not necessary for other diagnostic group.

Since this group is meant to apply to virtual text, such a variant seems appropriate and an improvement in consistency over the current group.

Alternatively, we could use a "semantic" treesitter group like `@attribute` or `@label` (haven't thought about which would be most appropriate).
comment_data.diff_hunk:

           hl_group = 'Visual',

+            { capture_name, 'DiagnosticVirtualTextHint' },

           hl_group = 'Visual',

-            { capture_name, 'Title' },
+            { capture_name, 'DiagnosticVirtualTextHint' },

comment_data.body:
Yes, my reasoning was what Christian said, this is displayed as virtual text next to the code, `DiagnosticHint` is usually displayed on its own. I don't really agree with "what if we change the UI in the future", if the UI changes there might be all kinds of other changes that go with it.

But I don't mind using the regular DiagnosticHint too much, it's a small detail but still an improvement over Title.

comment_data.body: Yup, door is still open for an even better highlight group; there is no strong "right" group here (yet).
